revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Use Indian English|date=January 2016}} The '''energy policy of India''' is largely defined by the country's expanding [[energy crisis|energy deficit]] and increased focus on developing [[alternative energy|alternative sources of energy]],<ref name=Deficit>[https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2011/03/09/indias-widening-energy-deficit/ India's Widening Energy Deficit]</ref><ref name=Energy1>[https://www.scribd.com/doc/58789317/Energy-Resources-in-India "Energy resources in India"]</ref> particularly [[Nuclear power in India|nuclear]], [[solar power in India|solar]] and [[Wind power in India|wind]] energy. India ranks 81 position in overall energy self-sufficiency at 66% in 2014.<ref name=profile/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iea.org/Sankey/#?c=India&s=Balance |title= India- Energy balance, IEA |accessdate=6 April 2017}}</ref>
The [[primary energy]] consumption in India is the third biggest after China and USA with 5.6% global share in 2017.<ref name= bp17>{{cite web|url=https://www.bp.com/content/dam/bp/en/corporate/pdf/energy-economics/statistical-review/bp-stats-review-2018-full-report.pdf |title=BP Statistical Review 2018|accessdate=15 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usdebtclock.org/energy.html |title=World energy consumption clock |publisher=US debt clock org |accessdate=6 August 2014}}</ref> The total primary energy consumption from crude oil (221.1 Mtoe; 29.34%), natural gas (46.6 Mtoe; 6.18%), coal (424 Mtoe; 56.26%), nuclear energy (8.7 Mtoe; 1.15%), hydro electricity (30.7 Mtoe; 4.07%) and [[Renewable energy in India|renewable power]] (21.8 Mtoe; 2.89%) is 753.7 [[Tonne of oil equivalent|Mtoe]] (excluding traditional biomass use) in the calendar year 2017.<ref name= bp17/> In 2017, India's net imports are nearly 198.8 million tons of crude oil and its products, 25.7 Mtoe of LNG and 129.8 Mtoe coal totaling to 354.3 Mtoe of primary energy which is equal to 47% of total primary energy consumption. About 75% of India's electricity generation is from [[fossil fuel]]s. India is surplus in electricity generation and also marginal exporter of electricity in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=160105 |title=India becomes Net Exporter of Electricity for the first Time|accessdate=15 June 2018}}</ref> India is largely dependent on fossil fuel imports to meet its energy demands – by 2030, India's dependence on energy imports is expected to exceed 53% of the country's total energy consumption.<ref name=Deficit/> In 2009-10, the country imported 159.26 million tonnes of crude oil which amounts to 80% of its domestic crude oil consumption and, in 2017 27.7% of the country's total imports were oil imports.<ref name=Deficit/><ref>[http://www.eia.doe.gov/cabs/india/Full.html India Energy Profile – EIA] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110427165037/http://www.eia.doe.gov/cabs/india/Full.html |date=27 April 2011 }}</ref> By the end of calendar year 2015, India has become a power surplus country with huge power generation capacity idling for want of electricity demand.<ref name=nocap>{{cite web | url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/india-wont-need-extra-power-plants-for-next-three-years-says-government-report/articleshow/52545715.cms | title=India wont need extra power plants for next three years – Says government report| accessdate=13 January 2016}}</ref> India ranks second after China in renewables production with 208.7 Mtoe in 2016.<ref name=profile>{{cite web | url=http://energyatlas.iea.org/#!/profile/WORLD/IND | title=India – country energy profile, IEA| accessdate=13 January 2017}}</ref>
In 2015-16, the [[List of countries by energy consumption per capita|per-capita energy consumption]] is 22.042 Giga Joules (0.527 [[Tonne of oil equivalent|Mtoe]] ) excluding traditional biomass use and the [[List of countries by energy intensity|energy intensity]] of the Indian economy is 0.271 Mega [[Joule]]s per INR (65 [[Conversion of units|kcal]]/INR).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiaenvironmentportal.org.in/files/file/Energy_Statistics_2017.pdf| title= Energy statistics, 2017 of India (page#40)|publisher= CSO, GoI|accessdate=10 March 2017}}</ref> Due to [[economic development in India|rapid economic expansion]], India has one of the world's fastest growing energy markets and is expected to be the second-largest contributor to the increase in global energy demand by 2035, accounting for 18% of the rise in global energy consumption.<ref name="renewable">[http://ireeed.gov.in/glossary]</ref> Given India's growing energy demands and limited domestic oil and gas reserves, the country has ambitious plans to expand its [[renewable energy in India|renewable]] and most worked out nuclear power programme.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiaenergy.gov.in/default.php |title=India energy security scenarios up to 2047 (IESS 2047) |publisher= NITI Aayog, GoI|accessdate=29 August 2014}}</ref> India has the world's fourth largest wind power market and also plans to add about 100,000 MW of solar power capacity by 2020.<ref name= gwec>{{cite web|url=http://gwec.net/wp-content/uploads/vip/GWEC_PRstats2017_EN-003_FINAL.pdf|title=Global Wind Statistics 2017|accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/will-try-to-achieve-pledged-renewable-energy-targets-in-less-than-four-and-half-years-piyush-goyal/articleshow/49687054.cms |title=Will try to achieve pledged renewable energy targets in less than four and half years: Piyush Goyal|accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref> India also envisages to increase the contribution of nuclear power to overall electricity generation capacity from 4.2% to 9% within 25 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/economy-policy/slowdown-not-to-affect-india-s-nuclear-plans-109012100091_1.html |title=Slowdown not to affect India's nuclear plans |publisher=Business-standard.com |date=21 January 2009 |accessdate=22 August 2010}}</ref> The country has five nuclear reactors under construction (third highest in the world) and plans to construct 18 additional nuclear reactors (second highest in the world) by 2025.<ref>[https://www.economist.com/blogs/dailychart/2011/03/global_nuclear_power Going nuclear, The Economist]</ref>
Indian solar power PV tariff has fallen to {{INRConvert|2.44}} per [[Kilowatt hour|kWh]] in May 2017 which is lower than any other type of power generation in India.<ref name=tariff>{{cite web|title=Solar power tariffs drops historic low at Rs 2.44 per unit |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/solar-power-tariff-drops-to-historic-low-at-rs-2-44-per-unit/articleshow/58649942.cms|accessdate=21 May 2017}}</ref> In the year 2016, the levelized tariff in US dollars for solar PV electricity has fallen below 2.42 cents/kWh.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://renewables.seenews.com/news/update-abu-dhabi-confirms-usd-24-2-mwh-bid-in-solar-tender-540324 |title=Abu Dhabi confirms US$ 24.2/MWh bid in solar tender |accessdate=2016-09-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.utilities-me.com/news/12062-utility-scale-solar-pv-tariff-hits-new-low-at-0024kwh-as-dubai-adds-250mw-of-pv-to-700mw-csp-project |title=Utility Scale Solar PV Tariff Hits New Low At $0.024/KWh As Dubai Adds 250 MW Of PV To CSP Project |accessdate=4 November 2018}}</ref> Also the international tariff of [[concentrated solar power|solar thermal storage power]] plants has fallen to US$0.063/kWh, which is cheaper than fossil fuel plants.<ref name=chile>{{cite web |url=https://cleantechnica.com/2017/03/13/solarreserve-bids-24-hour-solar-6-3-cents-chile/|title=SolarReserve Bids 24-Hour Solar At 6.3 Cents In Chile |accessdate= 29 August 2017}}</ref><ref name=aus>{{cite web |url=http://helioscsp.com/solarreserve-awarded-au78mwh-concentrated-solar-power-contract/|title=Solar Reserve awarded AU$78/MWh Concentrated Solar Power contract |accessdate= 23 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://helioscsp.com/uaes-push-on-concentrated-solar-power-should-open-eyes-across-world/|title=UAE’s push on concentrated solar power should open eyes across world|accessdate= 26 September 2017}}</ref> The cheaper hybrid solar power (mix of solar PV and solar thermal storage power) need not depend on costly and polluting coal/gas fired power generation for ensuring stable grid operation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://helioscsp.com/dispatchable-solar-concentrated-solar-power-broke-price-records-in-2017/ |title=Dispatchable Concentrated Solar Power Broke Price Records in 2017 |accessdate= 22 September 2017}}</ref> Solar electricity price is going to become the benchmark price for deciding the other fuel prices (petroleum products, natural gas/[[biogas]]/LNG, CNG, LPG, coal, lignite, biomass, etc.) based on their ultimate use and advantages.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2016/05/18/3778623/new-economics-solar-plus-battery-storage/|title=Storing The Sun's Energy Just Got A Whole Lot Cheaper |accessdate= 23 May 2016}}</ref><ref name=food1/>
{{Pie chart |thumb = right |caption = '''India: Total primary energy use of 775 [[Tonne of oil equivalent|Mtoe]] in 2013'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eia.gov/beta/international/analysis.cfm?iso=IND&src=home-b6 |title=India was the third-largest energy consumer in 2013|accessdate=29 July 2016}}</ref><ref name=IEAsearch>{{cite web|url=http://www.iea.org/statistics/statisticssearch/ |title= IEA Statistics Interactive Search|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> |label1 = Coal|color1 = Black |value1 = 44 |label2 = Biomass and waste|color2 = Green |value2 = 23 |label3 = Petroleum & oth. liquids|color4 = Pink |value3 = 23 |label4 = Natural gas|color3 = #FF6600 |value4 = 6 |label5 = Nuclear|color5 = Red |value5 = 1 |label6 = Hydroelectric|color6 = DodgerBlue |value6 = 2 |label7 = Other renewables |color7 = Gold |value7 = 1 }}
==Oil and gas== {{See also|Oil and gas industry in India}} [[File:ONGC Oil Platform.jpg|thumb|right|An [[ONGC]] platform at [[Bombay High]] in the [[Arabian Sea]]]] [[File:Oil Balance India.svg|thumb|India's oil deficit]] [[File:Gas Balance India.svg|thumb|Gas Balance of India]] India ranks third in oil consumption with 212.7 million tons in 2016 after USA and China.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/commodities/news/oil-consumption-grows-fastest-in-india/articleshow/59228022.cms |title= Oil consumption grows fastest in India|accessdate=20 June 2017}}</ref> During the calendar year 2015, India imported 195.1 million tons crude oil and 23.3 million tons refined petroleum products and exported 55 million tons refined petroleum products. India has built surplus world class refining capacity using imported crude oil for exporting refined petroleum products. The net imports of crude oil is lesser by one fourth after accounting exports and imports of refined petroleum products.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.bp.com/content/dam/bp/pdf/energy-economics/statistical-review-2016/bp-statistical-review-of-world-energy-2016-full-report.pdf|title= BP Statistical Review of world energy 2016 (page 19)|accessdate=21 April 2016}}</ref> Natural gas production was 29.2 billion cubic meters and consumption 50.6 billion cubic meters during the calendar year 2015.
During the financial year 2012–13, the production of crude oil is 37.86 million tons and 40,679 million standard cubic meters (nearly 26.85 million tons) [[natural gas]]. The net import of crude oil & petroleum products is 146.70 million tons worth of Rs 5611.40 billions. This includes 9.534 million tons of [[LNG]] imports worth of Rs. 282.15 billions.<ref name=png2013>{{cite web |url=http://petroleum.nic.in/docs/pngstat.pdf |title=Indian PNG statistics |accessdate=25 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141205032742/http://petroleum.nic.in/docs/pngstat.pdf |archivedate=5 December 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Internationally, LNG price (One [[British thermal unit|mmBtu]] of LNG = 0.1724 barrels of crude oil (boe) = 24.36 cubic meters of natural gas = 29.2 litres [[Diesel fuel|diesel]] = 21.3 kg [[Liquefied petroleum gas|LPG]]) is fixed below crude oil price in terms of heating value.<ref name="srwew">{{cite web | url=https://www.bp.com/content/dam/bp/pdf/energy-economics/statistical-review-2016/bp-statistical-review-of-world-energy-2016-full-report.pdf | title=Statistical Review of world energy 2016| accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.ferc.gov/market-oversight/mkt-gas/overview/ngas-ovr-lng-wld-pr-est.pdf |title= Estimated World LNG Landed Prices|accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref> LNG is slowly gaining its role as direct use fuel in road and marine transport without [[regasification]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.livemint.com/Industry/PXl8ybCFVEJiKRhL2FUGJP/LNGbuses-to-debut-in-Kerala-import-capacity-to-be-doubled.htmlf |title= LNG-buses to debut in Kerala, import capacity to be doubled: Dharmendra Pradhan|accessdate=13 October 2016}}</ref><ref>[http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/companies/petronet-pitches-for-lng-as-auto-fuel/article2004320.ece Petronet pitches for LNG as auto fuel]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.theicct.org/sites/default/files/publications/ICCTwhitepaper_MarineLNG_130513.pdf |title= Assessment of the fuel cycle impact of liquefied natural gas as used in international shipping|accessdate=6 June 2014}}</ref> By the end of June 2016, LNG price has fallen by nearly 50% below its [[Liquefied natural gas#Oil parity|oil parity]] price making it more economical fuel than diesel/gas oil in transport sector.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://oilprice.com/Energy/Energy-General/The-US-Drives-Forward-To-Become-A-Player-On-The-World-LNG-Market.html| title=The US Drives Forward To Become A Player On The World LNG Market| accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| title=Bunker fuel spot price |url=http://www.mabux.com |accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref> In 2012-13, India consumed 15.744 million tons petrol and 69.179 million tons diesel which are mainly produced from imported crude oil at huge foreign exchange out go. Use of natural gas for heating, cooking and electricity generation is not economical as more and more locally produced natural gas will be converted into LNG for use in transport sector to reduce crude oil imports.<ref>[http://www.gastechnology.org/Training/Documents/LNG17-proceedings/Transport-13-Jim-Harger-Presentation.pdf The On-Road LNG Transportation Market in the US]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://uk.reuters.com/article/energy-transportfuel-idUKL6E8IB1XK20130124 |title= Gas at the gates of oil's transport fuel citadel|accessdate=6 June 2014}}</ref> In addition to the conventional natural gas production, [[coal gasification]], [[coal bed methane]], [[coal mine methane]] and [[Biogas digesters]] / [[Renewable natural gas]] will also become source of LNG forming decentralised base for production of LNG to cater to the widely distributed demand.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/oil-and-gas/india-trucking-into-gas-age-as-govt-clears-norms-for-lng-stations/60235480| title=India trucking into gas age as govt clears norms for LNG stations| accessdate=27 August 2017}}</ref><ref name=techno>{{cite web|url= http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0959652617317262| title=Techno-economic and environmental analysis of coal-based synthetic natural gas process in China| accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.igu.org/sites/default/files/node-page-field_file/IGU%20-%20World%20LNG%20Report%20-%202014%20Edition.pdf| title=Chapter 7 of World LNG Report – 2014 Edition| accessdate=17 April 2015}}</ref> There is possibility to convert most of the heavy duty vehicles (including diesel driven rail engines) into [[Natural gas vehicle|LNG fuelled vehicles]] to reduce diesel consumption drastically with operational cost and least pollution benefits.<ref name=energy>{{cite web|url= http://petroleum.nic.in/docs/reports/autopol.pdf |title= Sections 10.1.3 to 10.2.8, Auto Fuel Vision and policy, 2025, GoI |accessdate=16 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.lngfacts.org/lng-market/lng-vehicles/ |title= LNG vehicles |accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.lngvehiclefuel.com/why.html|title= Why LNG for heavy vehicles? |accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> Also, the break even price at user end for switching from imported coal to LNG in electricity generation is estimated near US$6/mmBtu.<ref name=WR2015>{{cite web| url=http://igu.org/sites/default/files/node-page-field_file/IGU-World%20LNG%20Report-2015%20Edition.pdf| title=Page 71 of World LNG Report – 2015 Edition| accessdate=17 June 2015}}</ref> The advent of cheaper [[CNG carrier|marine CNG transport]] will restrict LNG use in high end transport sector to replace costly liquid fuels leaving imported [[Compressed natural gas|CNG]] use for other needs.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.hellenicshippingnews.com/launch-of-jayanti-baruna-worlds-first-cng-carrier/| title=Launch of Jayanti Baruna: World’s First CNG Carrier| accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.platts.com/IM.Platts.Content/ProductsServices/ConferenceandEvents/2013/pc302/presentations/Lyndon_Ward.pdf| title=Marine CNG Transportation| accessdate=17 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.lng-world.com/lngshipping2015/Slides/Day%202/Bima%20Putrajaya%20PT%20Pelayaran%201015.pdf| title=Compressed Natural Gas (CNG) Shipping in Indonesia| accessdate=17 March 2017}}</ref> As the marine CNG transport is economical for medium distance transport and has fast unloading flexibility at many ports without costly unloading facilities, they have become alternate solution to [[Submarine pipeline|submarine gas pipelines]].<ref>{{cite web| url=https://hotcopper.com.au/documentdownload?id=uOMxKKzFkiWRTLKhOROKAxjvTDYC6w%2B8zRKZp%2FJvke92GA%3D%3D| title=GEV secures site for CNG export terminal at port of Chabahar, Iran for gas supply to India| accessdate=27 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.pacmar.com/story/2017/01/01/features/gas-carriers-theyve-come-a-long-way/481.html?m=true| title=Gas carriers they have come a long way| accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref>
The state-owned Oil and Natural Gas Corporation (ONGC) acquired shares in oil fields in countries like Sudan, Syria, Iran, and Nigeria – investments that have led to diplomatic tensions with the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://knowledge.allianz.com/en/globalissues/safety_security/energy_security/energy_security_oil_electricity_gas_coal_india.html|title = Energy Security India, Allianz Knowledge|accessdate = 3 July 2008|authorlink = Thilo Kunzemann|date = 27 May 2008}}</ref> Because of political instability in the Middle East and increasing domestic demand for energy, India is keen on decreasing its dependency on [[OPEC]] to meet its oil demand, and increasing its [[energy security]]. Several Indian oil companies, primarily led by [[ONGC]] and [[Reliance Industries]], have started a massive hunt for oil in several regions in India, including [[Rajasthan]], [[Krishna Godavari Basin]] and [[north-east India|north-eastern Himalayas]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/oil-gas/bp-india-head-sashi-mukundan-says-india-can-produce-10-15-tcf-of-gas-by-2022/articleshow/53726019.cms|title = BP India says India can produce 10-15 tcf of gas by 2022|accessdate = 17 August 2016}}</ref>
India has nearly 63 [[Cubic foot|tcf]] technically recoverable resources of [[shale gas]] which can meet all its needs for twenty years if exploited.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/oil-and-gas/geecl-plans-to-exploit-shale-worth-2-78-billion-at-its-raniganj-south-block/66636544 |title = GEECL plans to exploit shale worth $2.78 billion at its Raniganj (South) block|accessdate = 15 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://newsbase.com/topstories/private-entities-explore-shale-oil-and-gas-india |title = Private Entities To Explore Shale Oil And Gas In India|accessdate = 17 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Essar Oil & Gas to spend $ 1 bn in Raniganj for shale gas |accessdate= 13 July 2018 |url=https://www.essar.com/essar-oil-gas-to-spend-1-bn-in-raniganj-for-shale-gas/ }}</ref> India is developing an offshore gas field in [[Mozambique]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.naturalgasasia.com/indian-state-owned-energy-firms-plan-6-bn-investment-in-mozambique-gas-sector-15288|title = Indian State Owned Energy Firms Plan $6 bn Investment in Mozambique Gas Field|accessdate = 3 May 2015|authorlink = Thilo Kunzemann|date = 27 May 2008}}</ref> The proposed [[Iran-Pakistan-India pipeline]] is a part of India's plan to meet its increasing energy demand.
==Coal== [[File:Coal mine in Dhanbad, India.jpg|thumb|A coal mine in [[Jharkhand]] state]] {{See also|Coal by country|Coal mining in India}} India has the world's 4th largest [[Coal by country|coal reserves]]. In India, coal is the bulk of primary energy contributor with 56.90% share equivalent to 411.9 Mtoe in 2016.<ref name= bp17/> India is the third top [[Coal mining|coal]] producer in 2013 with 7.6% production share of coal (including lignite) in the world. Top five hard and [[brown coal]] producing countries in 2013 (2012) are (million tons): [[Energy in China|China]] 3,680 (3,645), [[Energy in the United States|United States]] 893 (922), India 605 (607), [[Energy in Australia|Australia]] 478 (453) and [[Energy in Indonesia|Indonesia]] 421 (386). However, India ranks fifth in global coal production at 228 mtoe (5.9%) in 2013 when its inferior quality coal tonnage is converted into tons of oil equivalent.<ref name="srwew"/> Coal-fired power plants account for 59% of India's installed electricity capacity.<ref>{{cite web|title=Power sector at a glance: All India data|publisher=Ministry of Power, Government of India|date=September 2013|url=http://www.powermin.nic.in/indian_electricity_scenario/introduction.htm}}</ref><ref name="World Coal Institute – India">{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcoal.org/pages/content/index.asp?PageID=402|title=The coal resource, a comprehensive overview of coal|last=|first=|date=March 2009|website=|publisher=World Coal Institute|access-date=}}</ref> After electricity production, coal is also used for cement production in substantial quantity.<ref>{{cite web|title=Coalnomics|date=September 2014|url=http://indianpowersector.com/home/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/Coalnomics-Brochure-1.pdf}}</ref> In 2013, India imported nearly 95 Mtoe of steam coal and coking coal which is 29% of total consumption to meet the demand in electricity, cement and steel production.<ref name="srwew"/> [[Petroleum coke|Pet coke]] availability, at cheaper price to local coal, is replacing coal in cement plants.<ref>{{cite web|title=Why imported pet coke dampened Coal India's cement linkage auction|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/why-imported-petcoke-dampened-coal-india-s-cement-linkage-auction-117033100997_1.html|accessdate=9 April 2017}}</ref>
[[Gasification]] of coal or lignite or [[Petroleum coke|pet coke]] produces [[syngas]] or [[coal gas]] or [[Coke (fuel)|coke oven gas]] which is a mixture of hydrogen, carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide gases.<ref>{{cite web|title= Coal gas can help lower import bill by $10 billion in 5 years: Coal Secy|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/economy-policy/coal-gas-can-help-lower-import-bill-by-10-billion-in-5-years-coal-secy-117030500463_1.html/|accessdate=5 March 2017}}</ref> Coal gas can be converted into [[Substitute natural gas|synthetic natural gas]] (SNG) by using [[Fischer–Tropsch process]] at low pressure and high temperature.<ref>{{cite web|title= Test Year for Chinese Coal-Based SNG|url=https://www.platts.com/IM.Platts.Content%5Caboutplatts%5Cmediacenter%5Cpdf%5Cinsight-nov12-sng.pdf|accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> Coal gas can also be produced by underground [[coal gasification]] where the coal deposits are located deep in the ground or uneconomical to mine the coal.<ref>{{cite web|title= Chinese firm plans Thar coal mining in Pakistan|url=http://www.steelguru.com/raw_material_news/Chinese_firm_plans_Thar_coal_mining_in_October/273972.html |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> [[CNG]] and [[LNG]] are emerging as economical alternatives to diesel oil with the escalation in international crude oil prices.<ref>{{cite web|title= LNG use in High horse power off road vehicles|url=https://www.ngvamerica.org/vehicles/high-horsepower/|accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> [[Dakota Gasification Company|Synthetic natural gas production]] technologies have tremendous scope to meet the transport sector requirements fully using the locally available coal in India.<ref name=techno/><ref>{{cite web|title= Next energy revolution will be on roads and railroads|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/commoditiesNews/idAFL6N0QI1Q920140812?sp=true|accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> [[Dankuni]] coal complex is producing syngas which is piped to the industrial users in Calcutta.<ref>{{cite web|title= GAIL, Coal India in pact to expand Dankuni gas project|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.in/2004/02/15/stories/2004021501330200.htm |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Reliance Jamnagar coal gasification project|url=http://gasification2016.missionenergy.org/presentation/ril.pdf|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> Many coal based fertiliser plants which are shut down can also be retrofitted economically to produce SNG as LNG and CNG fetch good price by substituting imports.<ref>{{cite web|title= Coal India, Gail to invest 9000 crores in Talcher Plant|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/indl-goods/svs/chem-/-fertilisers/coal-india-gail-to-invest-rs-9000-crore-in-talcher-plant/articleshow/45626357.cms|accessdate=25 December 2014}}</ref> Recently, Indian government fixed the natural gas price at producer end as US$5.61 per mmbtu on [[Heat of combustion|net calorific value]] (NCV) basis, which is at par with the estimated SNG price from coal.<ref>{{cite web|title= Govt raises natural gas price to $5.61 per unit|url=http://www.thehindu.com/business/Industry/govt-raises-natural-gas-price-to-561-per-unit/article6514987.ece|accessdate=25 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.hceco.com/HCEI105001.pdf |title= Conversion of Coal to Substitute Natural Gas (SNG) |accessdate=6 August 2014}}</ref>
==Bio-fuels== [[File:gasification.gif|frame|Gasification of [[Biochar|Char]] / Coal]] [[File:pyrolysis.svg|frame|[[Pyrolysis]] of [[carbonaceous]] fuels]] {{See also|Second-generation biofuels}} [[Gasification]] of bio mass yields [[wood gas]] or syngas which can be converted into [[substitute natural gas]] by [[Methanation]]. Nearly 750 million tons of non edible (by cattle) biomass is available annually in India which can be put to higher value addition use and substitute imported crude oil, coal, LNG, urea fertiliser, nuclear fuels, etc. It is estimated that renewable and carbon neutral biomass resources of India can replace present consumption of all fossil fuels when used productively.<ref name=Energy1/><ref>[https://www.scribd.com/doc/58789356/Productive-Usage-of-Biomass "Productive usage of Biomass"]</ref>
Huge quantity of imported coal is being used in pulverised coal-fired power stations. Raw biomass can not be used in the pulverised coal mills as they are difficult to grind into fine powder due to [[Caking (chemical engineering)|caking]] property of raw biomass. However biomass can be used after [[Torrefaction]] in the pulverised coal mills for replacing imported coal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.biofuelsdigest.com/bdigest/2016/10/20/torrefied-biomass-available-efficient-co2-neutral-and-economic-likely-the-best-solid-biomass-on-the-market/|title=Torrefied Biomass: Available, Efficient, CO2 Neutral and Economic – likely the best solid biomass on the market|accessdate=6 April 2017}}</ref> North west and southern regions can replace imported coal use with torrefied biomass where surplus agriculture/crop residual biomass is available.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/government-press-release/cea-has-written-to-all-states-to-use-5-10-of-118020801216_1.html| title=CEA has written to all States to use 5-10% of biomass pellets with coal for power generation in thermal power plants|accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/power/ntpc-invites-bids-for-procurement-of-agro-residue-for-its-dadri-power-plant/62832238 | title=NTPC invites bids for procurement of agro Residue for its Dadri power plant|accessdate=8 February 2018}}</ref> Biomass power plants can also get extra income by selling the Renewable Purchase Certificates (RPC).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/economy/renewable-purchase-obligations-enforcement-is-not-our-remit-power-regulator/article4428240.ece|title=Renewable purchase obligations enforcement is not our remit: Power regulator|accessdate=6 April 2017}}</ref>
In cement production, carbon neutral biomass is being used to replace coal for reducing carbon foot print drastically.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zkg.de/en/artikel/zkg_Geocycle_secures_biomass_needs_from_local_farmers_in_India_3116884.html |title=Lafargeholcim - Geocycle secures biomass needs from local farmers in India |accessdate=21 June 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.solarpaces.org/new-iea-report/ |title=New IEA Report: Renewable Energy for Industry |accessdate=21 June 2018 }}</ref>
[[Biogas]] or natural gas or methane produced from farm/agro/crop/domestic waste can also be used for producing protein rich feed for cattle/fish/poultry/pet animals economically by cultivating ''[[Methylococcus capsulatus]]'' bacteria culture in a decentralised manner near to the rural / consumption areas with tiny land and water foot print.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/oil-and-gas/indrapratha-gas-mahindra-mahindra-join-hands-to-stop-stubble-burning/62986917|title=Indrapratha Gas, Mahindra & Mahindra join hands to stop stubble burning|accessdate=20 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/power/360-degree-plan-to-convert-cattle-dung-into-energy/63022527|title=360-degree plan to convert cattle dung into energy|accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref><ref name=food>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ntva.no/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/04-huslid.pdf |title=BioProtein Production |access-date=31 January 2018}}</ref><ref name=food1>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/2112298-food-made-from-natural-gas-will-soon-feed-farm-animals-and-us/ |title=Food made from natural gas will soon feed farm animals – and us |access-date=31 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cargill.com/2016/new-venture-selects-cargill-tennessee-to-produce-feedkind |title=New venture selects Cargill’s Tennessee site to produce Calysta FeedKind® Protein |access-date=31 January 2018}}</ref> With the availability of CO<sub>2</sub> gas as by product from these units, cheaper production cost of [[algae oil]] from [[algae]] or [[Spirulina (dietary supplement)|spirulina]] particularly in tropical countries like India would displace the prime position of crude oil in near future.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2015/01/20150121-algenol.html#more |title=Algenol and Reliance launch algae fuels demonstration project in India |accessdate=29 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/ExxonMobil-Announces-Breakthrough-In-Renewable-Energy.html |title=ExxonMobil Announces Breakthrough In Renewable Energy |accessdate=20 June 2017}}</ref>
India’s three Oil Marketing Companies (OMCs) are currently setting up 12 second-generation ethanol plants across the country which will collect agriculture waste from farmers and convert it into bio-ethanol.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/oil-and-gas/india-can-replace-rs-1-lakh-crore-worth-of-hydrocarbon-imports-by-bio-fuels-pradhan/59498753 |title=India can replace Rs 1 lakh crore worth of hydrocarbon imports by bio-fuels: Pradhan |accessdate=8 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/oil-and-gas/bio-fuel-business-to-pick-up-in-india-atul-mulay-praj-industries/63535349 |title=Bio-fuel business to pick up in India: Atul Mulay, Praj Industries |accessdate=30 March 2018}}</ref> In 2018, India has set target to produce 15 million tons of biogas/bio-CNG by installing 5,000 large scale commercial type biogas plants which can produce daily 12.5 tons of bio-CNG by each plant.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/oil-and-gas/compressed-biogas-to-beat-petrol-and-diesel-with-30-higher-mileage/66675432 |title=Compressed biogas to beat petrol and diesel with 30% higher mileage |access-date=18 November 2018}}</ref>
The former [[President of India]], Dr. [[A. P. J. Abdul Kalam]], was a strong advocaters of [[Jatropha]] cultivation for production of [[bio-diesel]].<ref name="Kalam supports Jatropha cultivation">{{cite web |url=http://indiaenews.com/2006-06/10698-kalam-attend-jatropha-planters-convention.htm|title=Kalam to attend Jatropha planters' convention|publisher= India eNews Pvt. Ltd.|accessdate=8 July 2006}}</ref> He said that out of the 6,00,000 km² of waste land that is available in India over 3,00,000 km² is suitable for Jatropha cultivation. Once the plant is grown, it has a useful lifespan of several decades. During its life Jatropha requires very little water when compared to other cash crops. A plan for [[Jatropha incentives in India|supplying incentives]] to encourage the use of Jatropha has been coloured with green stripes.
==Nuclear power== {{Further information|Nuclear power in India}} [[File:Kudankulam NPP.jpg|200 px|left|thumb|The Kudankulam Nuclear power plant (2x1000 MW) in [[Tamil Nadu]] while under construction]] India boasts a quickly advancing and active nuclear power programme. It is expected to have 20 GW of nuclear capacity by 2020, though it currently stands as 9th in the world in terms of nuclear capacity.
An Achilles' heel of the Indian nuclear power programme, however, is the fact that India is not a signatory of the [[Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons|Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty]]. This has many times in its history prevented it from obtaining nuclear technology vital to expanding its nuclear industry. Another consequence of this is that much of its programme has been domestically developed much like its nuclear weapons programme. The [[United States-India Peaceful Atomic Energy Cooperation Act]] seems to be a way to get access to advanced nuclear technologies for India.
{{further information|India's three-stage nuclear power programme}} India has been using imported enriched uranium and is under International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards, but it has developed various aspects of the nuclear fuel cycle to support its reactors. Development of select technologies has been strongly affected by limited imports. Use of heavy-water reactors has been particularly attractive for the nation because it allows uranium to be burnt with little to no enrichment. India has also done a great amount of work in the development of a [[India's three stage nuclear power programme|thorium-centred fuel cycle]]. While uranium deposits in the nation are extremely limited, there are much greater reserves of thorium, and it could provide hundreds of times the energy with the same mass of fuel. The fact that thorium can theoretically be utilised in heavy water reactors has tied the development of the two. A prototype reactor that would burn uranium-plutonium fuel while irradiating a thorium blanket is under construction at the Madras/Kalpakkam Atomic Power Station.
Uranium used for the weapons programme has been separate from the power programme using uranium from scant indigenous reserves.
==Hydro electricity== {{See also|Hydroelectric power in India}}
India is endowed with economically exploitable and viable hydro potential assessed to be about 125,570 MW at 60% [[capacity factor]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.worldenergy.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/WEResources_Hydropower_2016.pdf |title=World Energy Resources Hydro Power, 2016 |publisher= World Energy Council|accessdate=30 November 2017 }}</ref> India ranked fourth globally by underutilized hydro power potential. In addition, 6,780 MW in terms of installed capacity from Small, Mini, and Micro Hydel schemes have been assessed. Also, 56 sites for [[Pumped-storage hydroelectricity|pumped storage]] schemes with an aggregate installed capacity of 94,000 MW have been identified for catering to peak electricity demand and water pumping for irrigation needs. It is the most widely used form of [[renewable energy]] but the economically exploitable hydro power potential keeps on varying due to technological developments and the comparable cost of electricity generation from other sources.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/document/365955283/Harnessing-gigantic-hydro-power-potential-of-Indus-Jhelum-and-Chenab-rivers-in-India |title=Harnessing gigantic hydro power potential of Indus, Jhelum and Chenab rivers in India |accessdate=30 November 2017 }}</ref> The hydro-electric potential of India ranks 5th in terms of exploitable hydro-potential on global scenario.
The installed capacity of hydro power is 45,315 MW as of 31 May 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cea.nic.in/monthlyhpi.html |title=List of Hydro Electric Stations in the Country| publisher=Central Electricity Authority, GoI |accessdate=30 August 2018 }}</ref> India ranks sixth in [[hydro electricity]] generation globally after China, Canada, Brazil, USA and Russia. During the year 2017-18, the total hydro electricity generation in India is 126.123 billion kWh which works out to 24,000 MW at 60% capacity factor. Till now, hydroelectricity sector is dominated by the state and central government owned companies but this sector is going to grow faster with the participation of private sector for developing the hydro potential located in the [[Himalayas|Himalaya]] mountain ranges including north east of India.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.cea.nic.in/reports/proj_mon/he_execution.pdf| title=List of Hydro projects under execution | publisher=Central Electricity Authority, Ministry of Power, Government of India | date=April 2014 | accessdate=21 August 2014}}</ref> However the hydro power potential in central India forming part of [[Godavari River|Godavari]], [[Mahanadi River|Mahanadi]] and [[Narmada River|Narmada]] river basins has not yet been developed on major scale due to potential opposition from the tribal population.
[[Pumped-storage hydroelectricity|Pumped storage]] schemes are perfect centralised peaking power stations for the load management in the electricity grid. Pumped storage schemes would be in high demand for meeting peak load demand and storing the surplus electricity as India graduates from electricity deficit to electricity surplus. They also produce secondary /seasonal power at no additional cost when rivers are flooding with excess water. [[Grid energy storage|Storing electricity]] by other alternative systems such as [[Battery (electricity)|batteries]], [[Compressed air battery|compressed air storage]] systems, etc. is more costlier than electricity production by [[standby generator]]. India has already established nearly 6800 MW pumped storage capacity which is part of its installed [[List of power stations in India|hydro power plants]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://npti.in/Download/Hydro/Pumped%20Storage%20Hydro%20Power%20Plant,%20Electrical%20India,%20Nov,%202013.pdf |title=Pumped storage hydro power plant |accessdate=27 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140707211619/http://npti.in/Download/Hydro/Pumped%20Storage%20Hydro%20Power%20Plant%2C%20Electrical%20India%2C%20Nov%2C%202013.pdf |archivedate=7 July 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Wind power== [[File:India Windpower Installed capacity by year.png|thumb|300 px|Progress in India's installed wind power generating capacity since 2006]] {{main article|Wind power in India}} India has the fourth largest installed wind power capacity in the world.<ref name= gwec/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indiaenergyportal.org/images/big_maps/state_b.jpg |title=Wind atlas of India |accessdate=28 August 2014 }}</ref> As of 31 December 2017, the installed capacity of wind power was 32,848 [[megawatts|MW]] an increase of 4148 MW over the previous year<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianwindpower.com/news_views.html#tab0 |title=Indian Wind Energy and Economy |publisher=Indianwindpower.com|date= |accessdate=6 August 2013}}</ref><ref>[http://www.mnre.gov.in/mission-and-vision-2/achievements/ Ministry of New and Renewable Energy – Achievements]. Mnre.gov.in (31 October 2013). Retrieved on 6 December 2013.</ref> Wind power accounts nearly 10% of India's total installed power generation capacity and generated 52.666 billion kWh in the fiscal year 2017-18 which is nearly 3% of total electricity generation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cea.nic.in/reports/monthly/renewable/2018/renewable-03.pdf|title=Monthly Renewable Energy Generation Reports, CEA |accessdate= 6 May 2018}}</ref> The capacity utilisation factor is nearly 16% in the fiscal year 2017-18. The [[Ministry of New and Renewable Energy]] (MNRE) of India has announced a revised estimation of the potential wind power resource (excluding [[offshore wind power]] potential) from 49,130 MW assessed at 50m Hub heights to 102,788 MW assessed at 80m Hub height at 15% [[capacity factor]].
==Solar energy== {{Main article|Solar power in India|Growth of photovoltaics}} [[File:Solar Resource Map of India.png|thumb|Solar Resource Map of India]] India's [[solar energy]] insolation is about 5,000 T kWh per year (i.e. ~ 600 TW), far more than its current total primary energy consumption.<ref>[http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6VMY-4CSXM8T-2&_user=520880&_coverDate=10%2F01%2F2005&_alid=611831031&_rdoc=1&_fmt=full&_orig=search&_cdi=6163&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_ct=1&_acct=C000023460&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=520880&md5=fb8bc24f0ebe81f43f43d217306373c5 Sustainable production of solar electricity] with particular reference to the Indian economy (publication archived in ScienceDirect, shows numbers in detail, but needs subscription / access via university)</ref><ref>[http://www.renewingindia.org/finren.html Renewing India – Under Heading:Solar Photovoltaics]</ref> [[Solar power in India|India's]] long-term solar potential could be unparalleled in the world because it has the ideal combination of both high [[Insolation|solar insolation]] and a big potential [[consumer|consumer base]] density.<ref>[http://www.treehugger.com/files/2006/01/solar_leds_brig.php Solar LEDs Brighten Rural India's Future]</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/3623864.stm Solar plan for Indian computers]</ref> With a major section of its citizens still surviving off-grid, India's grid system is considerably under-developed. Availability of cheap solar can bring electricity to people, and bypass the need of installation of expensive grid lines. Also a major factor influencing a region's [[energy intensity]] is the cost of energy consumed for temperature control. Since cooling load requirements are roughly in phase with the sun's intensity, [[Air conditioning|cooling]] from intense solar radiation could make perfect energy-economic sense in the subcontinent, whenever the required technology becomes competitively cheaper.
Installation of [[solar power]] PV plants require nearly 2.0 hectares (5 acres) land per MW capacity which is similar to coal-fired power plants when life cycle coal mining, consumptive water storage & ash disposal areas are also accounted and hydro power plants when submergence area of water reservoir is also accounted. 1.6 million MW capacity solar plants can be installed in India on its 1% land (32,000 square km). There are vast tracts of land suitable for solar power in all parts of India exceeding 8% of its total area which are unproductive barren and devoid of vegetation.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://dolr.nic.in/dolr/wasteland_atlas.asp |title= Waste lands atlas of India, 2011 |accessdate=30 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.scribd.com/doc/58789333/Geographical-Area-and-Its-Effective-Utilization |title= Geographical Area and Its Effective Utilization|accessdate=30 May 2014}}</ref> Part of waste lands (32,000 square km) when installed with solar power plants can produce 2400 billion kWh of electricity (two times the total generation in 2013-14) with land productivity/yield of 0.9 million Rs per acre (3 Rs/kWh price) which is at par with many industrial areas and many times more than the best productive irrigated agriculture lands.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/renewable/this-gujarat-village-is-harvesting-a-sunny-crop/53473954 |title=This Gujarat village is harvesting a sunny crop |accessdate=30 July 2016}}</ref> Moreover, these solar power units are not dependent on supply of any raw material and are self productive. There is unlimited scope for solar electricity to replace all fossil fuel energy requirements (natural gas, coal, lignite and crude oil) if all the marginally productive lands are occupied by solar power plants in future. The solar power potential of India can meet perennially to cater per capita energy consumption at par with USA/Japan for the peak population in its [[demographic transition]].<ref>[http://populationpyramid.net/india/ Population pyramids of India from 1950 to 2100]</ref>
'''Solar thermal power''' [[File:Crescent Dunes Solar December 2014.JPG|thumb|Typical tower type CSP plant.]] The installed capacity of commercial [[concentrated solar power|solar thermal power]] plants in India is 227.5 MW with 50 MW in Andhra Pradesh and 177.5 MW in Rajasthan.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.energystorageexchange.org/projects/669 |title=DOE Energy storage database |accessdate=2017-08-21}}</ref> Solar thermal plants are emerging as cheaper (US 6.1 ¢/kWh) and clean [[load following power plant]]s compared to fossil fuel power plants.<ref name=aus/> They can cater the load/ demand perfectly and work as base load power plants when the extracted solar energy is found excess in a day.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://reneweconomy.com.au/aurora-what-you-should-know-about-port-augustas-solar-power-tower-86715/|title=Aurora: What you should know about Port Augusta’s solar power-tower |accessdate= 22 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://helioscsp.com/concentrated-solar-power-dropped-50-in-six-months/ |title=Concentrated Solar Power Dropped 50% in Six Months |accessdate= 30 October 2017}}</ref> Proper mix of solar thermal and [[Photovoltaics|solar PV]] can fully match the load fluctuations without the need of costly battery storage.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://solarthermalmagazine.com/2017/07/19/solarreserve-receives-environmental-approval-390-megawatt-solar-thermal-facility-storage-chile/|title=SolarReserve receives environmental approval 390 MW solar thermal facility storage in Chile |accessdate= 29 August 2017}}</ref><ref name=chile/>
'''Synergy with irrigation water pumping and hydro power stations''' [[File:Price history of silicon PV cells since 1977.svg|thumb|Price history of silicon PV cells since 1977. The great thing about solar power is that it is a technology and not a fuel. It is unlimited and the more it is deployed the cheaper it would be.<ref name=tariff/> While the more limited fossil fuels are used, the more expensive they become.]] The major disadvantage of solar power (PV type only) is that it can not produce electricity during the night time and cloudy day time also. In India, this disadvantage can be overcome by installing [[pumped-storage hydroelectricity]] stations. Ultimate electricity requirement for river water pumping (excluding ground water pumping) is 570 billion kWh to pump one cubic meter of water for each square meter area by 125 m height on average for irrigating 140 million hectares of net sown area (42% of total land) for three crops in a year.<ref>[http://www.cwc.nic.in/main/webpages/statistics.html#2 India – Land and Water Resources at a glance, CWC (accessdate 12 June 2014)]</ref> This is achieved by utilising all the usable river waters by [[Indian Rivers Inter-link|interlinking Indian rivers]] by envisaging [[coastal reservoir]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/document/390880621/Feasibility-of-coastal-reservoir-to-harness-Brahmaputra-and-Ganga-surplus-waters |title=Feasibility of coastal reservoir to harness Brahmaputra and Ganga surplus waters|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref> These river water pumping stations would also be envisaged with pumped-storage hydroelectricity features to generate electricity when necessary to stabilise the grid. Also, all existing and future hydro power stations can be expanded with additional pumped-storage hydroelectricity units to cater night time electricity consumption. Most of the ground water pumping power can be met directly by solar power during daytime. To achieve [[food security]], India needs to achieve [[water security]] which is possible only by [[energy security]] for harnessing its [[Water Resources in India|water resources]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Brown |first=Lester R. |date=29 November 2013 |title=India's dangerous 'food bubble' |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/nov/29/opinion/la-oe-brown-india-food-bubble-famine-20131129 |deadurl= |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |location= |publisher= |archiveurl=http://www.earth-policy.org/plan_b_updates/2013/update119 |archivedate=4 December 2013 |accessdate=10 December 2013}}</ref>
'''Electric vehicles''' {{See also|Electric vehicle industry in India}} The retail prices of [[Gasoline|petrol]] and [[Diesel fuel|diesel]] are high in India to make [[Electric vehicle|electricity driven vehicles]] more economical as more and more electricity is generated from solar energy in near future without appreciable environmental effects. During the year 2013, many [[Independent Power Producer|IPPs]] offered to sell solar power below 6.50 Rs/kWh to feed into the low voltage (< 33 KV) grid.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/states/solar-power-bidders-accept-rs-649unit-offer-from-ap/article4873499.ece|title= Solar power bidders accept Rs 6.49/unit offer from AP|accessdate=27 May 2014}}</ref> This price is below the affordable electricity retail tariff for the solar power to replace petrol and diesel use in transport sector.
The retail price of diesel is 53.00 Rs/litre in 2012-13. The affordable electricity retail price (860 kcal/kWh at 75% input electricity to shaft power efficiency) to replace diesel (lower heating value 8572 kcal/litre at 40% [[Brake specific fuel consumption|fuel energy to crank shaft efficiency]]) is 9.97 Rs/kWh. The retail price of petrol is 75.00 Rs/litre in 2012-13. The affordable electricity retail price (860 kcal/kWh at 75% input electricity to shaft power efficiency) to replace petrol (lower heating value 7693 kcal/litre at 33% fuel energy to crank shaft efficiency) is 19.06 Rs/kWh. In 2012-13, India consumed 15.744 million tons petrol and 69.179 million tons diesel which are mainly produced from imported crude oil at huge foreign exchange out go.<ref name=png2013/>
[[Vehicle-to-grid|V2G]] is also feasible with electricity driven vehicles to contribute for catering to the peak load in the electricity grid. The electricity driven vehicles would become popular in future when its energy storage / [[Electric vehicle battery|battery]] technology becomes more compact, lesser density, longer lasting and maintenance free.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/auto/plans-afoot-to-make-india-100-e-vehicle-nation-by-2030-piyush-goyal/articleshow/51557146.cms |title= Plans afoot to make India 100% e-vehicle nation by 2030. Piyush Goyal|accessdate=26 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.visualcapitalist.com/explaining-surging-demand-lithium-ion-batteries/ |title= Explaining the Surging Demand for Lithium-Ion Batteries|accessdate=5 May 2016}}</ref>
==Hydrogen energy== {{See also|Power to gas|List of fuel cell vehicles}} Hydrogen Energy programme started in India after joining the IPHE (International Partnership for Hydrogen Economy) in the year 2003. There are nineteen other countries including Australia, United States, UK, Japan, etc.<ref name=hydrogen>{{cite web|url=http://infohouse.p2ric.org/ref/45/44490.pdf|title=Hydrogen Fuel Cell Engines and Related Technologies |accessdate=28 August 2014}}</ref> This global partnership helps India to set up commercial use of [[Hydrogen economy|Hydrogen gas as an energy source]]. [[Ministry of New and Renewable Energy]] (MNRE) is the focal government agency associated with hydrogen energy development in India.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mnre.gov.in/file-manager/UserFiles/Draft-Report-on-Hydrogen-Energy-and-Fuel-Cells-A-Way-Forward.pdf|title= Hydrogen Energy and Fuel Cells in India|year=2016 |accessdate=28 August 2016}}</ref>
Hydrogen is a [[carbon neutral fuel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ronpaulforums.com/showthread.php?516089-Solar-power-crushes-its-own-record-for-cheapest-electricity-ever-anywhere-by-any-technology|title= Solar power crushes its own record for cheapest electricity ever, anywhere, by any technology |accessdate=22 October 2017}}</ref> Solar electricity prices in India have already fallen below the affordable price (≈ INR 5.00 per Kwh to generate 0.041 lb/Kwh hydrogen which is equivalent to 0.071 litres of petrol in terms of lower heating value) to make [[Hydrogen economy|hydrogen economical fuel]] by sourcing from [[High-pressure electrolysis|electrolysis of water]] to replace petrol/gasoline as transport fuel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/hydrogen-fuel-future-1.3640316|title=Hydrogen continues to be a fuel of the future |accessdate=28 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edmunds.com/fuel-economy/8-things-you-need-to-know-about-hydrogen-fuel-cell-cars.html|title=8 Things You Need To Know About Hydrogen Fuel-Cell Cars |accessdate=28 August 2016}}</ref><ref name=hydrogen/> Vehicles with [[fuel cell]] technology based on hydrogen gas are nearly twice more efficient compared to diesel/petrol fuelled engines.<ref name=hydrogen/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.energy.gov/sites/prod/files/2014/03/f9/thomas_fcev_vs_battery_evs.pdf |title=Fuel Cell and Battery Electric Vehicles Compared |accessdate=28 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eco-business.com/news/hydrogen-fuel-reaches-lift-off/|title=Hydrogen fuel reaches lift-off |accessdate=28 June 2017}}</ref> A luxury [[Fuel cell vehicle|hydrogen fuel cell car]] generates one litre of bottled quality drinking water for every 10 km ride which is a significant by product.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.caranddriver.com/toyota/mirai |title=2016 Toyota Mirai Fuel-Cell Sedan |accessdate=28 August 2016}}</ref> Any medium or heavy duty vehicle can be retrofitted in to fuel cell vehicle as its system [[power density]] (watts/litre) and system [[Power-to-weight ratio|specific power]] (watts/kg) are comparable with that of internal combustion engine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cenex-lcv.co.uk/2016/assets/downloads/lcv2016-presentations/presentation-zone/day1/ralph-clague.pdf |title=automotive fuel cell metrics|accessdate=28 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mahindrae2oplus.com/pages/buyers-guide/specifications |title=Mahindra electric car specifications |accessdate=28 August 2016}}</ref> The cost and durability of fuel cell engines with [[economies of scale]] production line are comparable with the petrol/diesel engines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.drive.com.au/motor-news/the-breakdown-hydrogen-on-the-horizon-20170623-gwxnp2.html |title=The breakdown: hydrogen on the horizon |accessdate=28 May 2017}}</ref>
The excess power generation capacity available in India is nearly 500 billion units/year presently and another 75,000 MW conventional power generating capacity is in pipeline excluding the targeted 175,000 MW renewable power by 2022.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/india-can-achieve-1-65-billion-units-of-electricity-next-year-piyush-goyal/articleshow/53103685.cms| title= India can achieve 1,650 billion units of electricity next year, Piyush Goyal |accessdate=9 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.cea.nic.in/reports/quarterly/tpmii_quarterly_review/2016/tpmii_qr-10.pdf | title=Review of progress of thermal power projects under execution. October 2016 (see page 27)| accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref><ref name=nocap/> The hydrogen fuel generated by 500 billion units of electricity can replace all diesel and petrol consumed by heavy and medium duty vehicles in India completely obviating the need of crude oil imports for internal consumption.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://auto.ndtv.com/news/tata-motors-reveals-indias-first-hydrogen-fuel-cell-bus-1652559|title=Tata Motors reveals India's first hydrogen fuel cell bus|accessdate=25 January 2017}}</ref> Converting petrol/diesel driven road vehicles in to fuel cell electric vehicles on priority would save the huge import cost of crude oil and transform the stranded electricity infrastructure in to productive assets with major boost to the overall economic growth.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.scribd.com/document/332195358/Economics-of-fuel-cell-electric-vehicles-and-needed-transport-sector-policy-in-India|title=Economics of fuel cell electric vehicles and needed transport sector policy in India|accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref>
== Electricity as substitute to imported LPG and kerosene== {{See also|Energy in India}} The net import of [[Liquefied petroleum gas|LPG]] is 6.093 million tons and the domestic consumption is 13.568 million tons with Rs. 41,546 crores subsidy to the domestic consumers in 2012-13.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/oil-and-gas/india-challenges-china-as-worlds-biggest-lpg-importer/62263809|title= India challenges China as world's biggest LPG importer|accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref><ref name=png2013/> The LPG import content is nearly 40% of total consumption in India. The affordable electricity retail price (860 kcal/kWh at 90% heating efficiency) to replace LPG (lower heating value 11,000 kcal/kg at 75% heating efficiency) in domestic cooking is 6.47 Rs/kWh when the retail price of LPG cylinder is Rs 1000 (without subsidy) with 14.2 kg LPG content. Replacing LPG consumption with electricity reduces its imports substantially.
The domestic consumption of [[Kerosene]] is 7.349 million tons with Rs. 30,151 crores subsidy to the domestic consumers in 2012-13. The subsidised retail price of Kerosene is 13.69 Rs/litre whereas the export/import price is 48.00 Rs/litre. The affordable electricity retail price(860 kcal/kWh at 90% heating efficiency) to replace Kerosene (lower heating value 8240 kcal/litre at 75% heating efficiency) in domestic cooking is 6.00 Rs/kWh when Kerosene retail price is 48 Rs/litre (without subsidy).
During the year 2013-14, The [[Capacity factor|plant load factor]] (PLF) of coal-fired thermal power stations is only 65.43% whereas these stations can run above 85% PLF comfortably provided there is adequate electricity demand in the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cea.nic.in/reports/monthly/generation_rep/tentative/mar14/opm_11.pdf|title= All India coal fired stations performance (2013-14)|accessdate=27 May 2014}}</ref> The additional electricity generation at 85% PLF is nearly 240 billion units which is adequate to replace all the LPG and Kerosene consumption in domestic sector.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/economy/policy/arvind-panagariya-pitches-for-electricity-as-clean-cooking-option-to-lpg/articleshow/51786931.cms|title= Niti Aayog pitches for electricity as clean cooking option to LPG|accessdate=13 April 2016}}</ref> The incremental cost of generating additional electricity is only their coal fuel cost which is less than 3 Rs/kWh. Enhancing the PLF of coal-fired stations and encouraging domestic electricity consumers to substitute electricity in place of LPG and Kerosene in household cooking, would reduce the government subsidies and idle capacity of thermal power stations can be put to use economically. The domestic consumers who are willing to surrender the subsidised LPG / Kerosene permits or eligible for subsidised LPG / Kerosene permits, may be given free electricity connection and subsidised electricity tariff.
During the year 2014, IPPs are offering to sell solar power below 5.50 Rs/kWh to feed into the high voltage grid.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianpowersector.com/home/2014/08/madhya-pradesh-plans-indias-largest-solar-power-plant/|title= Madhya Pradesh plans India's largest Solar Power Plant)|accessdate=3 August 2014}}</ref> This price is below the affordable electricity tariff for the solar power to replace LPG and Kerosene use (after including subsidy on LPG & Kerosene) in domestic sector. Two wheelers and three wheelers consume 62% and 6% of petrol respectively in India. The saved LPG/[[Autogas]] replaced by electricity in domestic sector can be used by [[LPG-powered scooter|two and three wheelers]] with operational cost and least pollution benefits.<ref name=energy/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gasenergyaustralia.asn.au/reports-and-submissions/industry-reports/?cp=1|title= India's autogas growth looks certain|accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref> By the middle of 2016, LPG spot prices have fallen below crude oil parity price in terms of heat content (one barrel crude oil is equal to 123.5 kg of LPG) due to LPG glut in the market<ref>{{cite web|url=http://3mgas.vn/news/saudi-aramco-lpg-prices-per-metric-tonne-mt-n145.html|title= Saudi Aramco LPG Prices|accessdate=31 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/usa-lpg-china-idINKCN0ZZ0NI|title= Oil traders lose millions as LPG glut shocks market|accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref> Instead of using LPG as heating fuel in domestic sector, for higher end usage, [[Liquefied petroleum gas|LPG]] can be also converted into [[alkylate]] which is a premium [[gasoline]] blending stock because it has exceptional antiknock properties and gives clean burning.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bpnews.com/index.php/publications/magazine/current-issue/830-u-s-is-world-s-largest-lpg-exporter-but-when-will-market-balance | title= BPN Butane – Propane news| accessdate=10 April 2017}}</ref>
==Power to food== The Methane / natural gas generated from water with electricity, can be utilized to produce protein rich feed for fish/poultry/cattle which is known as [[Power-to-gas#Power to methane|power to food]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.carbontrust.com/media/672719/calysta-feedkind.pdf |title=Assessment of environmental impact of FeedKind protein |accessdate=20 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=food/><ref name=food1/>
==Energy trading with neighbouring countries== The [[List of countries by electricity consumption|per capita electricity consumption]] is low compared to many countries despite cheaper [[Electricity pricing|electricity tariff]] in India.<ref>{{Cite web| title=Tariff & duty of electricity supply in India | url=http://www.cea.nic.in/reports/articles/eandc/tariff_2014.pdf | work= | publisher=CEA, Govt. of India | date=March 2014 | accessdate= 12 August 2014}}</ref> Despite low electricity per capita consumption in India, the country is going to achieve surplus electricity generation during the 12th plan (2012 to 2017) period provided its coal production and transport infrastructure is developed adequately.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://businesstoday.intoday.in/story/power-minister-piyush-goyal-on-power-surplus-electricity/1/218807.html|title=Power Minister Piyush Goyal says power available for free | accessdate=1 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.nldc.in/2013-03-12-10-34-42/daily-report|title=Daily report of power situation, Ministry of Power, GoI, | accessdate=17 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.nldc.in/ |title= See Reports section, National load dispatch centre, Ministry of Power, GoI, | accessdate=17 February 2013}}</ref> India has been exporting electricity to [[Energy policy of Bangladesh|Bangladesh]] and Nepal and importing excess electricity in Bhutan.<ref>{{Cite web| title=India To Export Another 500 MW Power To Bangladesh In Next 12 Months: NLDC| url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-cm/india-to-export-another-500-mw-power-to-bangladesh-in-next-12-months-nldc-115071400538_1.html | accessdate= 15 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | title=Table 13, Monthly operation report, March 2015 | url=http://www.nldc.in/attachments/article/265/Monthly%20Report%20March%202015.pdf | work= | publisher=POSOCO, Govt. of India | date=March 2015 | accessdate=24 April 2015 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150524081145/http://www.nldc.in/attachments/article/265/Monthly%20Report%20March%202015.pdf | archivedate=24 May 2015 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Surplus electricity can be exported to the neighbouring countries in return for natural gas supplies from [[Energy policy of Pakistan|Pakistan]], Bangladesh and [[Energy in Myanmar|Myanmar]].<ref>{{Cite web| title=India discussing natural gas swap with Russia, involving China| url=http://www.financialexpress.com/india-news/india-discussing-natural-gas-swap-with-russia-involving-china/467819/ | accessdate= 15 March 2017}}</ref>
Bangladesh, Myanmar and Pakistan are producing substantial natural gas and using for electricity generation purpose.<ref name=IEAsearch/> Bangladesh, [[Oil and gas industry in Myanmar|Myanmar]] and Pakistan produce 55 million cubic metres per day (mcmd), 9 mcmd and 118 mcmd out of which 20 mcmd, 1.4 mcmd and 34 mcmd are consumed for electricity generation respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/ |title= Select 'Energy' sections of Pakistan, Burma, Bangladesh, Nepal, Bhutan & Sri Lanka. The world Fact book.|accessdate=17 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-2-315979-LNG-The-whole-truth |title= LNG: The whole truth in Pakistan.|accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref> Whereas the natural gas production in India is not even adequate to meet its non-electricity requirements.
Bangladesh, Myanmar and Pakistan have proven reserves of 200 billion cubic metres (bcm), 1200 bcm and 500 bcm respectively.<ref name= bp17/> There is ample opportunity for mutually beneficial trading in energy resources with these countries.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.newindianexpress.com/business/news/Saarc-Chamber-Pushes-for-Seamless-Regional-Energy-Trade/2015/07/30/article2948453.ece|title=Saarc Chamber Pushes for Seamless Regional Energy Trade | accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref> India can supply its surplus [[Energy policy of Pakistan|electricity to Pakistan]] and Bangladesh in return for the natural gas imports by gas pipe lines.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/oil-and-gas/on-pm-modis-visit-myanmar-to-receive-first-lot-of-diesel-from-india/60339402|title=On PM Modi's visit, Myanmar to receive first lot of diesel from India| accessdate=2 September 2017}}</ref> Similarly India can develop on [[BOOT]] basis [[Energy in Bhutan|hydro power projects in Bhutan]], [[List of power stations in Nepal|Nepal]] and Myanmar. India can also enter into long term [[power purchase agreements]] with China for developing the [[Yarlung Tsangpo Grand Canyon|hydro power potential]] in [[Brahmaputra river]] basin of [[Tibet]] region. India can also supply its surplus electricity to [[Electricity sector in Sri Lanka|Sri Lanka]] by [[India–Sri Lanka HVDC Interconnection|undersea cable link]]. There is ample trading synergy for India with its neighbouring countries in securing its energy requirements.<ref name=Energy1/><ref name=Energy2/><ref name=Energy3/>
==Policy framework== In general, India's strategy is the encouragement of the development of [[renewable energy|renewable sources of energy]] by the use of incentives by the federal and state governments. Other examples of encouragement by incentive include the use of nuclear energy ([[India Nuclear Cooperation Promotion Act]]), promoting [[windfarm]]s such as [[Muppandal]], and [[solar energy]] ([[Ralegaon Siddhi]]).
A long-term [[energy policy]] perspective is provided by the Integrated Energy Policy Report 2006 which provides policy guidance on energy-sector growth.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://planningcommission.nic.in/reports/genrep/rep_intengy.pdf |title= Integrated Energy Policy Report 2006|accessdate=31 January 2015}}</ref> Increasing energy consumption associated primarily with activities in transport, mining, and manufacturing in India needs rethinking on India's energy production.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://oilprice.com/Energy/Energy-General/Continuously-Rising-Energy-Costs-Will-Cripple-The-Economy.html |title= Continuously Rising Energy Costs Will Cripple The Economy |accessdate=13 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://helioscsp.com/an-entirely-renewable-energy-future-is-possible/ |title= An entirely renewable energy future is possible |accessdate=13 September 2017}}</ref>
Recent steep fall in international oil prices due to [[Tight oil|shale oil]] production boom, would tilt the energy policy in favour of crude oil / natural gas.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://oilprice.com/Energy/Energy-General/A-Market-Collapse-Is-On-The-Horizon.html |title= A Market Collapse Is On The Horizon |accessdate=9 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/timworstall/2014/12/13/oils-heading-for-40-for-shale-oil-is-a-free-market-and-opecs-a-cartel/ |title= Oil's Heading For $40, For Shale Oil Is A Free Market And Opec's A Cartel |accessdate=9 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.energytrendsinsider.com/tag/opec/ |title= Everything Has Changed: Oil And The End Of OPEC |accessdate=31 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://oilprice.com/Energy/Energy-General/Why-The-Permian-Doesnt-Keep-OPEC-Awake-At-Night.html |title= Why The Permian Doesn't Keep OPEC Awake At Night |accessdate=21 April 2017}}</ref>
==Electricity generation== {{Main article|Electricity sector in India}} The installed capacity of utility power plants is 314.64 [[watt|GW]] as on 31 January 2017 and the gross electricity generated by utilities during the year 2015-16 is 1168.359 billion [[kWh]] which includes auxiliary power consumption of power generating stations. The installed capacity of captive power plants in industries (1 MW and above) is 50,289 MW as on 31 March 2017 and generated 197 billion kWh in the financial year 2016-17.<ref name="GES"/> In addition, there are nearly 75,000 MW aggregate capacity diesel generator sets with units sizes between 100 KVA and 1000 KVA.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/gensets-add-up-to-under-half-of-installed-power-capacity/|title= Gensets add up to under half of installed power capacity; August, 2014 |accessdate=13 May 2015}}</ref> All India [[List of countries by electricity consumption|per capita consumption of Electricity]] is nearly 1,122 kWh during the financial year 2016-17.<ref name=GES>{{cite web |url=http://www.cea.nic.in/reports/others/planning/pdm/growth_2017.pdf |title=Growth of Electricity Sector in India from 1947-2017 |publisher=CEA |accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> [[File:Indian girls making tea over open fire.jpg|thumb|Some rural areas in India remain to be connected to the electricity grid. Shown here villagers heating tea with the help of [[firewood]].]][[File:Rstps4.jpg|thumb|[[NTPC Ramagundam|Ramagundam Thermal Power Station]] (2600 MW), [[Telangana]] ]] '''Total installed Power generation Capacity (end of April 2017)'''<ref name="June14"/>
