revision.text:
[[Image:Sura-antenna.jpg|right|thumb|400px|View of antenna array at Sura site.]]
The '''Sura Ionospheric Heating Facility''', located near the small town of [[Vasilsursk]] about 100 km eastward from [[Nizhniy Novgorod]] in [[Russia]], is a [[laboratory]] for [[ionosphere]] research {{#tag:ref|{{cite web|title = sura nirfi.sci|url = http://sura.nirfi.sci-nnov.ru/indexe.html|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20020809060208/http://sura.nirfi.sci-nnov.ru/indexe.html|dead-url = yes|archive-date = August 9, 2002|accessdate = February 13, 2015}}}}. Sura is capable of radiating about 190 [[watt|MW]], [[effective radiated power]] (ERP) on short waves {{Citation needed|date=March 2013}}. This facility is operated by the radiophysical research institute [[NIRFI]] in [[Nizhny Novgorod]] {{Citation needed|date=March 2013}}. The Sura facility was commissioned in 1981 {{Citation needed|date=April 2013}}. Using this facility, Russian researchers studied the behaviour of the ionosphere and the effect of generation of low-frequency emission on modulation of ionosphere current. In the beginning, the Soviet Defense Department mostly footed the bill. The American [[HAARP]] [[ionospheric heater]], whose operation began in 1993, is similar to the Sura facility.
==Technical information== The frequency range of the heating facility is from 4.5 to 9.3 MHz. The facility consists of three 250 kW broadcasting transmitters and a 144 crossed dipole antenna-array with dimensions of 300 m x 300 m.
At the middle of the operating frequency range (4.5 – 9.3 MHz) a maximum zenith gain of about 260 (~24 dB) is reached, the ERP of the facility is 190 MW (~83 dbW).
==External links== *http://sura.nirfi.sci-nnov.ru/Photogalery/Photogalery.html{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} pictures of the facility *http://www.copernicus.org/EGU/annales/15/ag15/935.pdf (see page 2) *http://sura.nirfi.sci-nnov.ru/indexe.html{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} further information in Russian *http://english.pravda.ru/science/19/94/379/16227_hurricanes.html *http://esapub.esrin.esa.it/pff/pffv5n4/kloov5n4.htm {{coord|56.13|N|46.10|E|display=title}} <!-- it was given like this - so I assume they indeed meant hundreds of a degree, rather then minutes -->
[[Category:Buildings and structures in Nizhny Novgorod Oblast]] [[Category:Ionosphere]] [[Category:Research institutes in Russia]]

{{For|the novelette by Bruce Sterling|Taklamakan (story)}} {{Chinese|pic=Taklamakan desert.jpg|picsize=200px|piccap=View of the Taklamakan desert|order=st |s={{linktext|塔克拉玛干|沙漠}} |t={{linktext|塔克拉瑪干|沙漠}} |p=Tǎkèlāmǎgān Shāmò |poj=Thah-khek-lá-má-kan Soa-bo̍k |w=T'a<sup>3</sup>-k'e<sup>4</sup>-la<sup>1</sup>-ma<sup>3</sup>-kan<sup>1</sup> Sha<sup>1</sup>-mo<sup>4</sup> |xej=تَاكْلامَاقًا شَاموْ |uig=تەكلىماكان قۇملۇقى |uly=Teklimakan qumluqi |uyy=Təklimakan ⱪumluⱪi |usy=Тәклимакан қумлуқи |dungan=Такәламаган Шамә }}
The '''Taklamakan Desert''' {{IPAc-en|ˌ|t|æ|k|.|l|ə|.|m|ə|ˈ|k|æ|n}} ({{zh|s={{linktext|塔克拉玛干|沙漠}}|p=Tǎkèlāmǎgān Shāmò}}, [[Xiao'erjing]]: {{lang|zh-Arab|تَاكْلامَاقًا شَاموْ}}; {{lang-ug|تەكلىماكان قۇملۇقى}}; {{lang-dng|Такәламаган Шамә}}), also spelled "Taklimakan" and "Teklimakan", is a [[desert]] in southwest [[Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region]], [[northwest China]]. It is bounded by the [[Kunlun Mountains]] to the south, the [[Pamir Mountains]] and [[Tian Shan]] (ancient [[Mount Imeon]]) to the west and north, and the [[Gobi Desert]] to the east.
The name may be an [[Uyghur language|Uyghur]] borrowing of the [[Persian language|Persian]] {{lang|fa-Latn|tark}}, "to leave alone/out/behind, relinquish, abandon" + {{lang|fa-Latn|makan}}, "place".<ref>{{cite book |first=E. M. |last=Pospelov |title=Geograficheskiye nazvaniya mira |location=Moscow |publisher= |year=1998 |page=408 |isbn= }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |first=Gunnar |last=Jarring |title=The Toponym Takla-makan |journal=Turkic Languages |volume=1 |year=1997 |pages=227–40 }}</ref> Some sources claimed it means "Place of No Return", more commonly interpreted as "once you get in, you'll never get out" or similar.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yAgGHnENHjoC&pg=PA368#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=World Regional Geography |first= Joseph J. |last=Hobbs|page=368 |publisher=Wadsworth Publishing Co Inc|edition= 6th |date=14 December 2007|isbn=978-0495389507}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P1MBAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA141#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Traces in the Desert: Journeys of Discovery Across Central Asia|first= Christoph |last=Baumer |page=141 |publisher= B. Tauris & Company|isbn=9780857718327 |date=2008-06-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EXikxcbKW2YC&pg=PA12#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Foreign Devils on the Silk Road: The Search for the Lost Treasures of Central Asia |first= Peter |last=Hopkirk |page=12|publisher=Oxford University Press|date=1 November 2001|isbn=978-0192802118 }}</ref> Another plausible explanation suggests it is derived from [[Turki]] ''taqlar makan'', describing "the place of ruins".<ref>Tamm (2011), p. 139.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.travelchinaguide.com/attraction/xinjiang/korla/taklamakan.htm |title=Takla Makan Desert at TravelChinaGuide.com |accessdate=2008-11-24 }} But see Christian Tyler, ''Wild West China'', John Murray 2003, p.17</ref>
==Geography== [[File:Tarimrivermap.png|thumb|left|Taklamakan Desert and [[Tarim Basin]]]] [[File:Tarimbecken 3. Jahrhundert.png|thumb|left|Settlements, 3rd century CE.]] [[File:Taklamakan.png|thumb|left|Taklamakan by [[NASA World Wind]]]] The Taklamakan Desert has an area of {{convert|337000|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}},<ref name="Taklimakan Desert 2006">{{cite journal |title=The Age of the Taklimakan Desert |first=Jimin |last=Sun |first2=Tungsten |last2=Lou |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |volume=312 |issue=5780 |year=2006 |page=1621 |doi=10.1126/science.1124616 |pmid=16778048 }}</ref> making it slightly smaller than [[Germany]], and includes the [[Tarim Basin]], which is {{convert|1000|km}} long and {{convert|400|km}} wide. It is crossed at its northern and at its southern edge by two branches of the [[Silk Road]] as travellers sought to avoid the arid wasteland.<ref name="atlas">{{cite book |first=Paul G. |last= Ban |title=The Atlas of World Archeology |edition= |publisher=Check mark Books |location=New York |pages= 134&n dash; 135 |isbn= 978-0-8160-4051-3|year= 2000 }}</ref> It is the world's second largest shifting sand desert with about 85% made up of shifting sand dunes<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9110530/Takla-Makan-Desert |title=Taklamakan Desert |publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica |accessdate=2007-08-11 }} </ref> ranking 16th in size in a ranking of the world's [[List of deserts by area|largest deserts]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://geology.com/records/largest-desert.shtml |title=The World's Largest Desert |publisher=geology.com |accessdate=2007-08-22 }} </ref>
Some [[geographer]]s and [[ecology|ecologists]] prefer to regard the Taklamakan Desert as separate and independent from the [[Gobi Desert]] region to its east. {{citation needed|date=March 2014}}
[[China|The People's Republic of China]] has constructed two cross-desert highways. The [[Tarim Desert Highway]] links the cities of [[Hotan]] (on the southern edge) and [[Luntai]] (on the northern edge), and the [[Bayingol]] to [[Ruoqiang Town|Ruoqiang]] road crosses the desert to the east. In recent years, the desert has expanded in some areas, its sands enveloping farms and villages as a result of [[desertification]].
The [[Golmud-Korla Railway]] (presently, under construction; expected completion time, 2019) will cross the Taklamakan as well.
==Climate== [[File:Taklamakan-d12.jpg|thumb|Desert life near [[Yarkent County|Yarkand]]]] [[File:Taklamakan desert sand dunes landsat 7.png|thumb|Sand Dunes captured by NASA's Landsat-7]]
Because it lies in the [[rain shadow]] of the Himalayas, Taklamakan is a paradigmatic cold [[desert climate]]. Given its relative proximity with the cold to frigid [[air mass]]es in [[Siberia]], extreme temperatures are recorded in wintertime, sometimes well below {{convert|−20|C|0}}, while in summer they can rise up to {{convert|40|C|0}}. During the [[2008 Chinese winter storms]] episode, the Taklamakan was reported to be covered, for the first time in its history, entirely with a thin layer of snow reaching {{convert|4|cm|in}}, with a temperature of {{convert|−26.1|C|0}} in some observatories.<ref name = xinhuanetdesertsnow>{{cite news |title=China's biggest desert Taklamakan experiences record snow |publisher=Xinhuanet.com |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-02/01/content_7544946.htm |date=February 1, 2008 }}</ref>
Its extreme inland position, virtually in the very heartland of Asia and thousands of kilometres from any open body of water, accounts for the somewhat wide [[diurnal temperature variation]].
==Oasis== [[File:Alluvial fan, Taklimakan Desert, XinJiang Province, China, NASA, ASTER.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Molcha River|Molcha (Moleqie) River]] forms a vast [[alluvial fan]] at the southern border of the Taklamakan Desert, as it leaves the [[Altyn-Tagh]] mountains and enters the desert in the western part of the [[Qiemo County]]. The left side appears blue from water flowing in many streams. The picture is taken in May, when the river is full with the snow/glacier meltwater.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&hl=en&geocode=&q=38%C2%B053%E2%80%B228%E2%80%B3N,+82%C2%B010%E2%80%B240%E2%80%B3E&ie=UTF8&ll=37.301914,84.340668&spn=0.805076,1.203003&t=h&z=10 | title=38°53'28.0"n 82°10'40.0"e}}</ref>]]
The Taklamakan Desert has very little water, therefore it is hazardous to cross. Merchant caravans on the [[Silk Road]] would stop for relief at the thriving [[oasis]] towns.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1_41VGoCYU8C&pg=PA321&dq=Taklamakan+Desert |title=Spies Along the Silk Road |publisher= |accessdate=2007-08-07 |isbn=9780192802323 |author1=Hopkirk |first1=Peter |authorlink = Peter Hopkirk |year=2001 }} </ref> It was in close proximity to many of the ancient civilizations — to the Northwest is the [[Amu Darya]] basin, to the southwest the Afghanistan mountain passes lead to Iran and India, to the east is China, and even to the north ancient towns such as [[Almaty]] can be found.
The key oasis towns, watered by rainfall from the mountains, were [[Kashgar]], [[Marin (China)|Marin]], [[Niya (Tarim Basin)|Niya]], [[Yarkent County|Yarkand]], and [[Hotan|Khotan]] (Hetian) to the south, [[Kuqa]] and [[Turpan]] in the north, and [[Loulan]] and [[Dunhuang]] in the east.<ref name="atlas"/> Now, many, such as Miran and [[Gaochang]], are ruined cities in sparsely inhabited areas in the [[Xinjiang|Xinjiang Autonomous Region]] of the [[China|People's Republic of China]].<ref name="road">{{cite book |year=2004 |month= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ArWLD4Qop38C&pg=PA189 |title=The Silk Road: Trade, Travel, War and Faith |publisher= |accessdate=2007-08-25 |isbn=9781932476132 |author1=Whitfield |first1=Susan |last2=Library |first2=British }}</ref>
The archaeological treasures found in its sand-buried ruins point to [[Tocharians|Tocharian]], early [[Hellenistic]], [[India]]n, and [[Buddhist]] influences. Its treasures and dangers have been vividly described by [[Aurel Stein]], [[Sven Hedin]], [[Albert von Le Coq]], and [[Paul Pelliot]].<ref name="atlas2">{{cite web |url = http://www.ess.uci.edu/%7Eoliver/silk.html |title = The Silk Road |publisher = |accessdate = 2007-08-07 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20160315145417/http://www.ess.uci.edu/%7Eoliver/silk.html |archivedate = 2016-03-15 |df = }} </ref> [[Tarim Mummies|Mummies]], some 4000 years old, have been found in the region.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/16/science/16archeo.html |title=A Host of Mummies, a Forest of Secrets |accessdate=2014-12-28 |newspaper=The New York Times |date=2010-03-15 |last1=Wade |first1=Nicholas }}</ref>
Later, the Taklamakan was inhabited by [[Turkic peoples]]. Starting with the [[Han Dynasty]], the [[Chinese people|Chinese]] sporadically extended their control to the oasis cities of the Taklamakan Desert in order to control the important [[Silk Road|silk route]] trade across Central Asia. Periods of Chinese rule were interspersed with rule by Turkic, [[Mongols|Mongol]] and [[Tibetan people|Tibetan]] peoples. The present population consists largely of Turkic [[Uyghur people]] and ethnic [[Han people]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-pacific-16860974 Xinjiang territory profile], BBC News. May 7, 2011.</ref>
==Scientific exploration== This desert was explored by several scientists such as [[Xuanzang]], a monk in the [[7th century]] and by the archaeologist [[Aurel Stein]] in the [[20th century]].
Atmospheric studies have shown that dust originating from the Taklamakan is blown over the Pacific, where it contributes to cloud formation over the Western United States. Studies have shown that a specific class of mineral found in the dust, known as [[K-feldspar]], triggers ice formation particularly well. K-feldspar is particularly susceptible to corrosion by acidic atmospheric pollution such as nitrates and phosphates. Exposure to these constituents reduces the ability of the dust to trigger water droplet formation. Further, the traveling dust redistributes minerals from the Taklamakan to the western U.S.A. via rainfall.<ref name="The Dust Detectives">{{cite magazine |last=Fox |first=Douglas |date=2014-12-22 |title=The Dust Detectives |url=http://www.hcn.org/issues/46.22/the-dust-detectives |magazine=High Country News |volume=46 |issue=22 |access-date=2017-09-02}}</ref>
==In popular culture== The desert is the main setting for Chinese film series ''[[Painted Skin (2008 film)|Painted Skin]]'' and ''[[Painted Skin: The Resurrection]]''. The Chinese TV series ''[[Candle in the Tomb (TV series)|Candle in the Tomb]]'' is mostly spent in this desert as they are searching for the ancient city of Jinjue (see [[Niya (Tarim Basin)]].)
The issue #39 'Soft Places' of Neil Gaiman's ''[[The Sandman_(Vertigo)|The Sandman]]'' takes place in the desert, when [[Marco Polo]] gets lost in the desert.
==See also== *[[Bezeklik Thousand Buddha Caves]] *[[Cities along the Silk Road]] *[[List of deserts by area]] *[[Tarim Basin]] *[[Tarim mummies]] *[[Turpan water system]]
